paragraph.docTitle:
Correlational nutritional relationships and interactions between expansive holoparasite
Orobanche laxissima
and woody hosts on metal-rich soils

subSection.paragraph: ARTICLE INFO
Broomrape
Host
Soil–host–parasite transfer Environmental stress
Metal accumulation
Metal relocation Polyphenols Phenylethanoid glycosides
ABSTRACT

Plant parasitism by other plants, combined with abiotic environmental stress, offers a unique opportunity to study correlational nutritional relationships in terms of parasite–host interactions and their functional roles in nutrient cycling in ecosystems. Our study analysed the transfer of selected mineral elements, including heavy metals, from soil to different organs in hosts (
Punica granatum
and
Fraxinus angustifolia
) and from hosts to the expansive holoparasite (
Orobanche laxissima
) in cinnamonic soil habitats in Georgia (Caucasus). We also identified other correlated trophic and bioactive effects in the parasite–host relationship.
O. laxissima
was characterized by a high accumulation tendency for micro- and macroelements, such as K and Ca, and heavy metals, such as Zn, Ni, and Cd. Parasites can reduce the concentration of heavy metals in host tissues owing to this high accumulation tendency. In total, 85 compounds were identified in the examined parasite and its hosts. Despite the distinct phytochemical content of species of the infected host, the parasite produced specific metabolites with dominant phenylethanoid glycosides (PhGs), with acteoside and crenatoside being the primary dominant compounds - ca. 98% of all polyphenols. Polyphenols in parasite specimens that are correlated with Cu and Zn are antagonistic to polyphenols correlated with Fe, Pb, Cr, and Ni. The profile of polyphenols in the host species was both qualitatively and quantitatively distinct from the profile of the compounds in the parasite and between hosts (only acteoside in group PhGs was common between the parasite and
Fraxinus
host), which indicates the existence of a unique compound biosynthesis pathway in the parasite. Our results demonstrated that the parasite, particularly in its flowers, exhibited higher polyphenol content, antioxidative effects (ABTS-+, DPPH, and FRAP), and inhibitory effects.

subSection.paragraph: when compared to hosts, particularly regarding polyphenols ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020a , 2020b ).

Orobanchaceae is the largest and most widely distributed family of root-parasitic angiosperms, with 102 genera and over 2100 species ( Nickrent, 2020 ). Despite relatively low biomass, many species in this family negatively affect hosts, particularly invasive species in crops. However, most occur in seminatural habitats, and some form large populations affecting multiple hosts, communities, and other trophic levels.
Orobanche
L. (incl.
Phelipanche Pomel
) is the most diverse and numerous holoparasitic genus in the Orobanchaceae family, with over 200 described species ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2019 ). More than 70 natural products have been described from species in
Orobanche
s.l. ; however, only ca. thirty species were subjected to phytochemical analysis ( Scharenberg and Zidorn, 2018 ; Jedrejek et al., 2020 ). Holoparasitic Orobanchaceae are a rich source of metabolites belonging to the phenylethanoid glycosides (PhGs), which have been reported to exhibit multiple biological and medicinal effects ( Scharenberg and Zidorn, 2018 ). Owing to their unique properties, some holoparasitic species, such as
Cistanche Hoffmanns & Link
, are considered for cultivation in specific regions of China due to their long-term use in traditional Chinese medicine ( Xu et al., 2009 ; Wang et al., 2019 ). Recently, the use of
Orobanche
as food and medicine has been gaining increasing interest ( Shi et al., 2020 ). However, the amount and bioactivity of the polyphenolic compounds found in these parasites are very diverse and depend on both the host plant and organs of the parasite and environmental factors such as altitude ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020a , 2020b ). Recent studies have clearly shown that holoparasitic Orobanchaceae , particularly
Orobanche
s.l. , can accumulate significant amounts of toxic metals ( Bani et al., 2018 ; Turnau et al., 2018 ; Dimitrakopoulos et al., 2021 ). Parasitic plants are most often obtained for herbal medicine from natural or seminatural habitats that appear to be unpolluted; however, they can grow in mountain areas with a natural share of metal-rich soils, bedrock, or saline desert areas. In areas with soils that are naturally rich in toxic metals, the circulation of elements is often disturbed, and there is a shortage of water; however, deep-rooted hosts have access to the water table ( Pate et al., 1990 ).

In this study, we used
Orobanche laxissima Uhlich
& R¨atzel ( Orobanchaceae ) as a parasite on two hosts from distinct families,
Punica granatum
L. ( Lythraceae ) and
Fraxinus angustifolia Vahl (Oleaceae)
.
O. laxissima
appears to be polyphagous (infecting many unrelated host species) as the most expansive holoparasite species of the roots of trees in the Caucasus (Western Asia). It has been listed from the natural or seminatural forest and shrub habitats. However, our recent observations in horticulture and arboriculture suggest an important economic influence since it may spread to adjacent forest communities and cultivated areas and it has the potential to easily adapt to many different host trees. This is particularly notable because parasite populations can produce several thousand shoots ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020c , 2021) and indirectly affect local ecosystems.
Orobanche
s.l. species have rarely been observed to parasitize the roots of trees or shrubs. Only a few other species in the genus are reported to do so; for example,
O. lucorum A. Braun ex F.W. Schultz
is known to parasitize
Berberis
L. and rarely
Crataegus
L., while
Phelipanche libanotica (Schweinf. ex Boiss.)
Soj´ak has been found to parasitize
Prunus
L. (S´anchez Pedraja et al., 2016 ; Piwowarczyk et al., 2019 ).

To date, the chemical and mineral composition of
O. laxissima
has not been evaluated, and our study opens doors for its exploitation as a functional food and pharmacologic and therapeutic agent; moreover, this analysis elucidates the influence of host and contaminated soils on harvested parasitic herbs. We examined two localities, both in wooded communities, within the range of cinnamonic soils (fertile clay soils rich in humus) in Georgia (Caucasus) exhibiting significant concentrations of toxic metals in the soil. The objectives of our study were to (I) determine the accumulation and translocation of micro- and macroelements with toxic metals from soil to particular plant organs (in both the hosts and the parasite); (II) evaluate the nutritional value, phytochemical composition, and bioactivity of
O. laxissima
by comparing particular organs and of
P. granatum
and
F. angustifolia
by evaluating various organs in plants from different localities; (III) determine whether the compounds identified were synthesized by holoparasites or obtained from their host plants; (IV) determine whether the host species affects the qualitative and quantitative composition of parasitic polyphenols and bioactivity; and (V) evaluate the function of holoparasites in wooded ecosystems as keystone species, highlighting their potential effects on nutrient cycling.

heading.emphasis: 2.1. Macro-, microelements and heavy metals content

subSection.paragraph:
Punica granatum
and
Fraxinus angustifolia
with
Orobanche laxissima
parasitizing their root systems were grown in fertile humus-rich loamy cinnamonic soils. These soils were characterized by neutral pH and low

salt concentrations. The soils from Sighnaghi were significantly richer in Mg, K, and P, while those from Antoki were rich in Ca ( Table 1 , Fig. 1 ). Soils contaminated with heavy metals can result in higher concentrations of these metals in plants. In arable soils, Cu levels should not exceed 25–40 mg / 1000 g (Gruca-Kr´olikowska and Wacławek, 2006 ). In the studied soils, the highest Cu content was found in Sighnaghi soil ( 39.42 mg / 1000 g ). The high amount of Ca in the studied soils may have caused the low level of available Cu in the soil. In soils, the content of Zn permitted is up to 100 mg / 1000 g ( Kabata-Pendias et al., 1993 ). It was at 115 mg / 1000 g in soils from Sighnaghi. The Antoki site was characterized by a much higher Zn content ( 225.72 mg / 1000 g ). Ni is a toxic element with a high rate of accumulation by plants. High content of this element was found in the investigated soils ( 72.54–102.73 mg / 1000 g ). This resulted in its high concentration in the analysed parts of the hosts and parasite. In soils, the average Cr content is 30–40 mg / 1000 g , which is acceptable for agricultural use ( Kabata-Pendias and Pendias, 1999 ). In Sighnaghi soil, the Cr concentration reached 49.89 mg / 1000 g , which may lead to increased uptake by plants. In Sighnaghi and Antoki soils, Cd was present in small, natural amounts (
0.240 –0.412 mg
/ 1000 g ). In the studied soils, Pb was also present in natural amounts (17.49 and 23.71 mg / 1000 g ), indicating benignity to local plants ( Kabata-Pendias et al., 1993 ). Cobalt occurs in clay soils up to 12 mg / 1000 g (Kabata-- Pendias and Pendias, 1999). Sighnaghi and Antoki soils were rich in Co at different levels (9.32 and 12.80 mg / 1000 g , respectively) ( Tables 1 and 2 ).

The content of macroelements and heavy metals in the soil has a direct influence on plant uptake. Individual species have physiologically determined needs for macro- and microelements, but in general, they take up them in proportion to their soil content. Higher elemental content in the soil did not generally lead to higher uptake by the host.
P. granatum
leaves exhibited lower concentrations of Mg, Ca, K, Cu, Cr, Ni, and Zn than the leaves of
F. angustifolia
( Table 3 ). However,
O. laxissima
accumulated more K, Ca, Fe, and toxic Cr, Co, Cd, Pb, and Ni when parasitizing
P. granatum
than when parasitizing
F. angustifolia
( Table 3 ). We also found that flowers of
O. laxissima ,
regardless of host species, accumulated more Mg, Ca, Ni, and Zn and less Co and Fe than the stems of this species ( Table 3 , Fig. 1 ). The indicator organs of the parasites were characterized by a minimal ability to uptake Ca from the hosts. In the leaves of
F. angustifolia, Ca
was 14.49 g / 1000 g , but in the stem of
O. laxissima
parasitizing it, the concentration was more than ten times lower ( 1.37 g / 1000 g ).

The bioaccumulation of metals in the examined parasite largely depended on the host species and organs.
O. laxissima
is characterized by a high microelement and heavy metal accumulation tendency. The flowers and stems of
O. laxissima
strongly accumulated Cr in relation to the
P. granatum
host (bioaccumulation factor > 10) and Fe, Cd, and Ni, as well as Pb and Zn (bioaccumulation factor 1–10). However,
O. laxissima
parasitizing
F. angustifolia
accumulated Ni, Zn, Cu, and Fe in its flowers ( Fig. 2 ).

Additionally, our results also indicate an interesting relationship between the content of some elements in the soil–host–parasite ecological community, specifically considering the potential for human involvement in this system. The circulation of toxic heavy metals is particularly important. Holoparasites from the Orobanchaceae are widely used in herbal medicine, and the proven bioaccumulation capacity of some heavy metals requires better scientific recognition. Cu was present in both host and parasite specimens in amounts up to 12.4 mg / 1000 g . The uptake of Cu by the host was not related to the soil concentration. In contrast, Cu uptake by
O. laxissima
was proportional to the content in the host. The flowers of
O. laxissima
parasitizing
Fraxinus
exhibited Cu accumulation ( 11.62 mg / 1000 g ). Cu levels exceeding 20 mg / 1000 g in food products are toxic to humans. However, Cu deficiency in humans is more unfavourable than excessive consumption, as it disturbs many biological processes ( Uriu-Adams and Keen, 2005 ). The RDA of Cu, according to the Age-Related Eye Disease Study Research Group (2002) and Jarosz et al. (2017) , is 0.7–0.9 mg , and the upper limit is 10 mg ( SCF, 1993 ). The soils from Antoki were significantly richer in Zn than those from Sighnaghi. This was translated into a significantly higher uptake of this element by the host
Fraxinus
and the
Orobanche
parasitizing it. The highest Zn concentration was found in the flowers of
O. laxissima
(up to 45.84 mg / 1000 g ). In contrast, the content in the stem was significantly lower than that in the host. There are no standards defining the acceptable level of Zn in food products. It is considered necessary in low amounts for the proper functioning of living organisms. The daily human requirement for zinc is 15–20 mg ( WHO, 1989 ). According to SCF (1993) , it would be unwise to exceed a daily intake of 30 mg in adults. Ni is a toxic element with a high accumulation factor in
Orobanche
. Found its high concentration in the analysed parts of hosts (3.01–4.06) and the parasite ( 4.05–4.99 mg / 1000 g ). The average Ni content in fresh foods is 0.079 mg / 1000 g ( Rose et al., 2010 ) and should not exceed 0.5 mg / 1000 g (GB 2762–2012). Population exposure to nickel from food has decreased since 1976 ( 0.33 mg /day), and it has been relatively stable since 1982– 0.13 mg /day in the 2006 TDS ( Rose et al., 2010 ). Notably, high levels of this element indicate that consuming a small amount of stem of
O. laxissima
may pose a threat to human health. Despite the low level of Cr in the leaves of
P. granatum
( 0.06 mg / 1000 g ), the Cr content in the stem of the parasite reached 1.09 mg / 1000 mg . The translocation factor, which is the ratio between the metal content of the plant and the soil, is calculated to determine the degree of bioaccumulation. In this case, the bioaccumulation index was 18.1. In the
Orobanche laxissima
flowers (Sighnaghi, parasite on
P. granatum
), Cr was at an even higher level of 1.64 mg (bioaccumulation index 27.3). In fresh vegetables and fruit of other species, the average Cr level has been reported to be
0.007 –0.008 mg
/ 1000 g ( Rose et al., 2010 ). The daily requirement of an adult human for Cr is 0.2 mg /day ( Nascimento et al., 2015 ). The host plants and flowers of the parasite contained a typical Cd amount for most plants ( 0.2 mg / 1000 g ). However, in the stem of the parasite, the amounts of Cd were approximately tenfold higher at 1.85 and 2.53 mg / 1000 g when parasitizing
Fraxinus
and
Punica
hosts, respectively. For plants, the toxic amounts of Cd range > 3 mg / 1000 g ( Kabata-Pendias and Pendias, 1999 ); however, in food products, they should not exceed 0.2 mg / 1000 g (Journal of Laws 37/326). Humans should not consume more than 0.007 mg /kg body weight - weekly dose. Plants take up Co in proportion to their content in the soil ( Kabata-Pendias and Pendias, 1999 ). The leaves of
P. granatum
contained most of the Co ( 0.41 mg / 1000 g ). Tested
O. laxissima
also contained small amounts of Co regardless of host species, up to 0.36 mg / 1000 g . These amounts are much smaller than those in fruits, vegetables, and grains ( Kabata-Pendias and Pendias, 1999 ). Cobalt is an essential element for animal organisms. Humans consume an average of 0.04–0.05 mg Co a day, and its absorption is 50%. One-time consumption of high concentrations of Co ( 25–30 mg ) is toxic to humans ( Kabata-Pendias and Pendias, 1999 ). The host plants contained traces of Pb ( 0.01 mg / 1000 g ). A very low level of Pb was also

observed in
O. laxissima
parasitizing
Fraxinus
. Conversely,
O. laxissima
parasitizing
Punica
accumulated Pb to a level of 0.24 mg / 1000 g . In the flowers of
O. laxissima
parasitizing
P. granatum
and in the stems of that parasitizing

was also observed with a bioconcentration factor > 1. Despite significant accumulation, total amounts were low and remained safe for human consumption (up to 0.3 mg / 1000 g ).

subSection.paragraph:
Evaluating parasite–host interactions can offer novel insights into correlational nutritional relationships ( Yoder, 2001 ). In hemiparasitic species, litter often has higher concentrations of foliar nutrients than their hosts, for example, two-to fourfold greater for N and P, potentially making more resources available to co-occurring species in the vicinity of the hemiparasite ( Quested et al., 2003a ). The effects of hemiparasites on productivity and diversity should depend on whether the parasite more significantly reduces host growth (parasitism) or increases nutrient cycling (litter effects) ( Spasojevic and Suding, 2011 ). A recent study presented
Orobanche nowackiana Markgr.
(=
Phelipanche nowackiana (Markgr.) Sojak
´) ( Orobanchaceae ), which is an obligate serpentinophyte that parasitizes the Ni hyperaccumulator
Alyssum murale Waldst. & Kit. (Brassicaceae)
.
P. nowackiana
grows in many areas, including serpentine soils, and suggests sufficient mechanisms of parasite tolerance. Studies have shown that the parasite has higher P, K, and Na and lower N, Ca, Mg, Ni, Zn, Co, Mn, and Al concentrations than the host ( Bani et al., 2018 ).
P. nowackiana
proved to be a Ni accumulator with 299 mg / 1000 g in the leaves (scales) and 601 mg / 1000 g in tubercles and roots ( Bani et al., 2018 ).
P. nowackiana
and
P. nana (Rchb. f.)
Soj´ak in another study were found to have stem nickel concentrations above 1000 mg /kg, indicating that they are nickel hyperaccumulators ( Dimitrakopoulos et al., 2021 ). Interestingly, in a previous study ( Bani et al., 2018 ), after infection by
P. nowackiana
on
Alyssum
, there was a decline in Ni concentration in the host, which confirmed our observations and those of Turnau et al. (2018) . However, this infection could be a potential threat to the use of
A. murale
as a hyperaccumulator for Ni agromination ( Bani et al., 2018 ). The role of parasites in plant resistance to toxic trace elements in polluted soils remains unclear ( Llugany et al., 2009 ). Hemiparasitic
Odontites lutea
(L.) Clairv. ( Orobanchaceae ) parasitizing
Cistus
L. ( Cistaceae ) in polluted sites exhibit high Zn and Pb concentrations and low Fe/Cu ratios in shoot tissue without developing toxicity symptoms, but further analysis is needed to clarify whether tolerance may be achieved by transfer of these elements in chelated, less toxic forms from the metal-tolerant host or by specific mechanisms existing in the parasite ( Llugany et al., 2009 ). Moreover, facultative
O. lutea
accumulates 1.5 times more K than its host, while obligate parasites have four-to fivefold higher content in comparison with their hosts ( Joel et al., 2013 ). Despite different rates of xylem utilization in different species, obligate parasites, such as
Striga Lour.
and
Orobanche
appear to reach the same level of K accumulation ( Hibberd et al., 1999 ). Other minerals, such as Ca, Mg, and Na, were also reported to have the highest concentrations in holoparasites ( Abbes et al., 2009 ), but these rarely accumulate to levels higher than those in the host. Lower Mg concentrations in parasite specimens in our study are similar to those reported in other studies and may be due to a lack of chlorophyll ( Bani et al., 2018 ). However, a lack of change in host nutrient concentrations should not be considered indicative of a non-detrimental impact and may be maintained by reduced host growth ( Press and Phoenix, 2005 ).
Orobanche
infection reduces host biomass and growth, as well as elemental composition, particularly in leaves (e.g., Singh et al., 1971 ; Mauromicale et al., 2008 ; Fernandez-Aparicio et al., 2016 ; Bani et al., 2018 ). In
Orobanche
, an obligate holoparasite, all nutrients required for development must be derived from the host phloem and are expected to take up minerals only from its host ( Bani et al., 2018 ) because haustoria of these parasites lack a root hair zone, making them unable to take up water and mineral compounds from the soil ( Delavault, 2015 ).
Orobanche
exhibited higher P and K concentrations and lower N, Ca, and Mg than the hosts, suggesting selective mineral absorption ( Bani et al., 2018 ). This confirms the observation of Singh et al. (1971) , who also found high K and P concentrations in
Orobanche
. Our study showed similar results, with K at a higher concentration in parasites, but P was at a similar level in hosts. Moreover, the higher amount of K in the parasite might be related to the fact that K is transferred from host to parasite together with organic metabolites ( Coic et al., 1965 ), which may also be related to the absorption of other minerals.

subSection.paragraph:
The results showed that the content of polyphenolic compounds in the parasite specimens were dependent upon on the type of host and morphological parts ( Table 4 ). Thus, the content of the polyphenolic compounds in parasite on
P. granatum
host was 1.5 times lower than in parasite on
F. angustifolia
host. The average amount of bioactive compounds in the
P. granatum
host was 1.3 times higher than in the
F. angustifolia
host. Such differences can be due to the content of the polyphenolic compounds identified on the host plant. The parasite, irrespective of the host, was dominated by PhGs, particularly acteoside. It was at a higher level in flowers (3273 and 5095 mg / 100 g ) than in stems (2105 and 3781 mg / 100 g ). Similar relationships were found in several parasites collected in Poland . They were also dominated by acteoside ( Jedrejek et al., 2020 ). Similar observations were reported for
Cistanche armena
parasitizing two host species (
Alhagi maurorum Medik.
and
Salsola dendroides Pall.
) ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020a ). According to Abbes et al. (2014) , the concentration of polyphenols in the
Orobanche foetida Poir.
to
O. crenata
was between 3.02 and 19.99 mg GAE/g dry weight (DW), while the average amount of bioactive compounds in the
C. armena
parasite was 920 mg / 100 g DW ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020a ). Moreover, the average amount of analysed compounds in
O. laxissima
was 1.4 times higher in the flowers than in the stem. The stem of
O. laxissima
were richer in polyphenols and contained around 3.4 and 1.2 times more than the flowers of
C. armena
parasitizing
S. dendroides
and
A. maurorum
, respectively ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020a ). The bioactive compound diversity among morphological parts was observed in
Cistanche phelypaea
(L.) Cout.; the authors noted that the dominant metabolites observed in the flowers were glycoside and bartsioside, that in the stems was primarily acteoside, and those in the roots were echinacoside and tubuloside A ( Trampetti et al., 2019 ). Among the identified compounds, PhGs (mainly acteoside and crenatoside) were dominant compounds and accounted for 97.8% of all polyphenols on average. Moreover, flavonols (2%), and phenolic acid (0.2%) were the predominant observed flavonoids. According to Piwowarczyk et al. (2020a) , PhGs were predominantly identified in the parasite of
C. armena
.
O. laxissima
parasitizing
F. angustifolia
contained 1.5 times more phenylethanoid glucosides then that parasitizing
P. granatum
. The amount of flavonols and phenolic acids was highest in the
O. laxissima
parasitizing
P. granatum
. One exception to the accumulation trends observed is the acid identified only in the flowers of parasite on
P. granatum
host, while no acid was identified in the host itself. PhGs substances are abundant in medical plants as well as traditional Chinese medicines, and they exhibit anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, antibacterial, antioxidant, antivirus, cytotoxic, and immunomodulatory characteristics ( Xue and Yang, 2016 ).

Tables S 1–3
in the Supplementary Materials and Fig. 4 show the results for the flowers and leaves of
P. granatum
and fruits and leaves of
F. angustifolia
, which exhibited different profiles of polyphenolic compounds. This indicates a unique biosynthesis pathway for polyphenols. Acteoside is the only compound present in the parasite and host
F. angustifolia
, and this compound was likely not taken up from the host by the parasite because acteoside is present in both species ( Attanzio et al., 2019 ). The host actoside content was significantly lower (221 and 415 mg / 100 g ) than that of the parasite ( 2105–5095 mg / 100 g ). The results of colour analysis of the tested species suggest that host plants may influence the colour of indicator elements of the parasite and are presented in the Supplementary Materials ( Table S4 ).

However, the predominant compounds in the flowers of the
P. granatum
host were hydrolysable tannins (accounting for 95% of all polyphenols), with flavonoids accounting for 5%, while hydrolysable tannins in the leaves accounted for 100%. In the fruits and leaves of the
F. angustifolia
host, the major compounds include phenylethanoid glucosides and flavonols, which accounted for 38% and 34% of all compounds, respectively. The content of polyphenols in the flowers of both hosts was similar, whereas in the leaves of the
P. granatum
host, the amount of polyphenols was 2 times higher than that in the leaves of the
F. angustifolia
host ( Fig. 3 ). This difference was observed due to the specificity of the tested hosts in synthesizing different amounts of polyphenols ( Yisimayili et al., 2019 ; Kiss et al., 2020 ; Fale´et al., 2013). According to Amjad and Shafighi (2013) , the polyphenol content in the flowers of
P. granatum
was 944.75 mg GA/g DW and was 1.7 times lower in the flowers of the parasite. In turn,
P. granatum
peel in the study by
Fischer et al. (2011 a
, 2011b) contained 6.4 and 5.3 times more polyphenols than in the flowers and leaves of the
P. granatum
host. Recent data have presented some evidence for the sequestration of metabolites, such as alkaloids, flavonoids, and iridoid glycosides, by some hemi- and holoparasites from their host species ( Scharenberg and Zidorn, 2018 ; Scharenberg et al., 2019 ).

PhGs may be considered specialized metabolites synthesized by parasitic species because they are not typically present in host species ( Scharenberg and Zidorn, 2018 ); this likely occurs owing to the existence of a unique biosynthetic pathway, particularly in obligate parasites. Holoparasites, which are completely dependent on their hosts for nutrients, create different types of metabolites after their uptake; this process may affect other species and the whole ecosystem after litter decomposition. Moreover, PhGs play protective, antimicrobial, antistress, or resistance roles in plants (Jim´enez and Riguera, 1994 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. Quantification of polyphenols for parasite and hosts.

Fig. 4. Principal component analysis (PCA) for mineral compositions and phenolic content in
Orobanche laxissima (Orobanchaceae)
.
Antioxidant and inhibitory effects of parasite and host indicator parts based on locality.

subSection.paragraph: PCA for minerals and phenolic content of plants explained 86.16% of the total variance, with PC1 representing 58.12% and PC2 representing 28.04% ( Fig. 4 ). The statistical method pointed out three major parts. Our results show that there were many correlations between antioxidant capacity and mineral extractability. PCA demonstrated a close relationship between polyphenols 1, 3, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 15, and 16 and Cu and Zn. Polyphenols 5 and 6 were found to be poorly related to Cu, as were polyphenols 2 and 17 to Zn. A relationship among Ni, Cr, and, to a lesser extent, Pb was observed with polyphenols 4, 9, 17, 18, and 19 ( Fig. 4 ). A strong positive correlation between Fe and polyphenol 7 was also found. The increase in Cd and Co content limited the amount of polyphenols. Two of the studied polyphenols, 5 and 6, were not related to heavy metal content. Moreover, polyphenols that are correlated with Cu and Zn were antagonistic to polyphenols correlated with Fe, Pb, Cr, and Ni. Few studies have shown that polyphenols can chelate metals ( Corso et al., 2020 ; Kova´ˇcik et al., 2008).

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Determination of enzyme inhibition potency and antioxidant activity

subSection.paragraph:
The results show distinct, host-dependent antioxidant and diabetic properties among the tested parts of
O. laxissima
. The flowers of the parasite were characterized by significantly higher inhibitory activities than those of the stem ( Table 5 ). A similar relationship was found in the
Phelypaea tournefortii
parasite ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020b ), contrasting the finding in the
Cistanche armena
study ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020a ). The flowers were also characterized by higher antioxidative effects determined by ABTS-+, DPPH, and FRAP. The greatest differences were found in the DPPH method results. The flowers were characterized by antioxidative compounds that were twice as abundant as those in the stem. Other studies have also shown that parasite flowers exhibit a greater ability to chelate and reduce Fe ( Debouba et al., 2012 ). Antioxidative effects may be influenced by the host species, as confirmed by the results obtained for
C. armena ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020a )
and
C. violacea ( Debouba et al., 2012 )
.

Other studies have demonstrated higher scavenging activity on DPPH and ABTS- + radicals for stems compared to flowers ( Trampetti et al., 2019 ), which contrasts with the results obtained in this study. Higher polyphenol content may have influenced the higher effect of flowers. A similar relationship was observed for both hosts. Other authors also indicated that the antioxidant capacity is strongly correlated with the content of phenolic compounds, which confirms their dominant role ( Attia et al., 2020 ). Regardless of the indicator part of the parasite or host, the described parameters were much lower than those of other
Orobanche species
studied by Attia et al. (2020) .

A significant difference was found in the nitrate content, particularly in the indicator parts of the parasite in comparison with the hosts. The host leaves contained a nitrate concentration that was approximately seven times higher than that of the parasite stem ( Table 5 ). The stem of another parasite,
P. tournefortii ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020b )
, had a significantly lower nitrate content. The low concentration of nitrates in the parasite may be indicative of their intensive growth, rapid nitrate reduction, and rapid tissue development. The fast growth rate may also contribute to the increased uptake of other components, including heavy metals.

In this study,
O. laxissima
was characterized by a high accumulation capacity of micro- and macroelements, including heavy metals (particularly Zn, Ni, and Cd). This bioaccumulation depended on the examined organ of the parasite and the species of the host which it parasitizes. Higher elemental concentrations in the soil were correlated with increased uptake by plants. The profile of polyphenols in the host species was both qualitatively and quantitatively different from the profile of the compounds in the parasite. Increased accumulation of elements, including parasites, and the production of specific metabolites (in our case, PhGs) may have an enhanced protective effect against drought, pest, herbivore, and disease damage ( Boyd, 2007 ; Mehdawi et al., 2011 ; Rascio and Navari-Izzo, 2011 ). Moreover, polyphenols of parasites that are correlated with Cu and Zn are antagonistic to polyphenols correlated with Fe, Pb, Cr, and Ni. Our research indicates that parasites respond to disturbances in the ecosystem and can provide valuable information about the dynamics of the host-parasite relationship as well as the health of the ecosystem in response to pollution. Further research is required to determine whether parasites can be used as indicators of ecosystem stress and metalliferous soils. Soil environmental contamination can also suppress the immune response of host plants, thereby leading to an increase in the intensity of infection by the parasite due to synergistic effects. Similarly, pollution might not directly affect mistletoe growth on trees but makes them more susceptible to mistletoe infection (Kołodziejek et al., 2012). Parasites can reduce the content of heavy metals in the host. Parasites may help to provide a better understanding of the biological availability of pollutants in ecosystems. Parasites can be considered a keystone species, as parasitism itself as well as the ability of parasites to accumulate and convert high amounts of organic and inorganic compounds (in our case, PhGs) via distinct biochemical pathways affects parasite–host relationships as well as the entire ecosystem. Some mutualistic effects have been observed on trophic interactions in abiotic environments and other organisms ( Press and Phoenix, 2005 ). Future investigation into these relationships is needed, such as holoparasite litter and its impact on soil microbes or higher trophic levels.
O. laxissima
is the most common plant parasite in forest and scrub communities. It is the most expansive holoparasitic species in the Caucasus, with its individual populations having up to several thousand shoots. Hence, it can act as a moderator of trophic dependencies and the structure of communities, both during its flowering and active parasitizing process and after the decomposition of nutrient-rich litter, thus affecting the entire ecosystem.
O. laxissima
also has high bioactive potential; however, before medical use, it must be tested for heavy metal content or specifically cultivated for human consumption owing to its strong accumulation properties. Such accumulation characteristics have also been shown in studies of other holoparasitic species. They may be related to the physiology of holoparasites.

For this study, we selected the holoparasite
Orobanche laxissima
R¨atzel & Uhlich ( Orobanchaceae ) and two of its hosts,
Punica granatum
L. ( Lythraceae ) and
Fraxinus angustifolia Vahl (Oleaceae)
( Fig. 5 ).

O. laxissima
is an expansive polyphagous root holoparasite that infects many wild and sometimes cultivated trees and shrubs from families such as Betulaceae , Oleaceae , Aceraceae , and Fagaceae , including
Fraxinus
L.,
Fagus
L., and
Carpinus
L. species ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2019 ). Moreover, recent reports have indicated the potential parasitism of economically significant forest and fruit tree plantations, such as those of
P. granatum
( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020c , 2021). This organism has been identified in the Caucasus Mountains and Transcaucasia, particularly in Russia , Georgia , Armenia , Azerbaijan , and NE Turkey ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2019 ). This parasitic plant flowers from May to July and develops fruits from July to August.
O. laxissima
prefers moist, shady, or semi-shady areas in deciduous forests, particularly hornbeam-oak, hornbeam-beech, roadsides on the edge of the woods and roads, scrubs, and in submontane and montane zones ~ 200–2000 m . It spreads in mountain and foothill forests, shrubs, and plantations of the Caucasus, appearing very numerous, with as many as thousands of individual population sizes.

The first host,
P. granatum
, commonly known as pomegranate, is native to the Caucasus, the Himalayas in North Pakistan , and Northern India and is widely cultivated, although it often grows wild. Pomegranate is one of the first domesticated fruits and has been used in folk medicine and as a food for centuries. The plant’ s fruit, seeds, leaves, flowers, roots, and bark extracts exhibit extensive medicinal properties ( Shaygannia et al., 2015 ).
P. granatum
has been naturalized in some areas in Georgia , appertaining to relict species, which typically occur on slopes and plane regions with grey-cinnamonic and cinnamonic soils ( Lachashvili et al., 2017 ).

The second host,
F. angustifolia
, is native to central and southern Europe, northwest Africa, and southwest Asia.
F. angustifolia
occurs mainly in the lowlands in riparian and floodplain forests along large rivers, where it forms vast and continuous populations; rarely, it creates pure stands that are found only in optimum conditions as a pioneer species at higher altitudes. Usually, this ash is a dominant or a secondary species in mixed broad-leaved forests, forming stable and species-rich ecosystems. Parts of the plant are harvested for wood, food, and ornamental uses, and it has been reported to exhibit antioxidant, anti-

heading.emphasis: 4.1.2. Study site and general habitat structure

subSection.paragraph:
The study was conducted in
May 2019
in two localities in the Caucasus Mountains of southeast ( Kakheti province ) Georgia ( Western Asia ):

1. Sighnaghi, in direction to Tsnori, in roadside and hill scrub with wild and cultivated areas of
P. granatum
,
41 ◦ 37,375 ′ N
,
45 ◦ 56,303 ′ E
, 480 m a.s.l. The parasite population consisted of at least a ca. a thousand shoots, sometimes in one clump was ca. 100 individuals. A single pomegranate plant was parasitized by a few to hundred broomrape plants, and 10–20% of the ca. 1 ha location was infested.

2. Antoki near Sagarejo,
F. angustifolia
cultivation near the road, at the foot of the Greater Caucasus range, in the vicinity of Caucasian mixed hornbeam-oak forests,
41 ◦ 43 ′ 15,2 ′′ N
,
45 ◦ 22 ′ 19,7E
", 755 m a.s.l. The population of the parasite consisted of at least 2000 shoots. A single plant of ash was parasitized by several to 100 broomrape plants, and 30–40% of the approximately 1-ha location was infested.

Both localities occurred within the cinnamonic soil (Cambisols Chromic) range, which is clearly defined on the Georgia map and included as a memorial group of the soils in The Red Book of Soils of Georgia ( Kvrivishvili et al., 2018 ). Cinnamonic soils are distributed in the forest-steppe zone of East Georgia , mainly at altitudes of 500 (700)– 900 (1300) a.s.l., 4.8% (311600 ha) of the total territory. These soils are characterized by dark-brown and brown colours of humus horizons, small lumps and grainy structures, weakly alkaline or neutral reactions, moderate contents of humus, a negative water balance, a distinct clay mation process, predominant silicate iron on nonsilicates, horizons with clay formation and calcium carbonates throughout the profile ( Yigini et al., 2013 ; Urushadze et al., 2015 ).

Samples were collected with a soil rod with a diameter of 40 mm . They were used to prepare a pooled sample. The estimation of the content of minerals in dry weight plants and soil was carried out in accordance with the Polish standard using certified reagents. All tests were performed in three replications.

Samples, separately, flowers and stems (inflorescence stalk – aboveground part of the stem, with tuber – underground part of the stem) of the parasite
O. laxissima
were collected using a shovel and washed. Samples of the host species
P. granatum
(leaves and flowers, separately) and
F. angustifolia
(leaves and fruits, separately) infected by the parasite were collected from the aforementioned localities. Following harvesting under natural conditions, the materials were dried. Voucher specimens were deposited in the Herbarium (KTC) of Jan Kochanowski University in Kielce. The plant names were updated based on the International Plant Names Index (IPNI, 2020), the most recent data according to Piwowarczyk et al. (2019) and the Index of Orobanchaceae (S´anchez Pedraja et al., 2016 ).
4.2.3.1. Soil. Soil samples were collected to determine the macroelement and toxic metal concentrations in the soil. The samples were
collected in the rhizosphere zone of the attachments of the parasite with hosts, ca. 25 cm .

The pH of the soil in KCl and salinity were measured potentiometrically by the ELMETRON CX 742 instrument. The estimation of the content of minerals in dry weight was carried out in accordance with the Polish standard (PN) using certified reagents.

The contents of total forms in soil macro-, microelements and heavy metals were determined after mineralization in HNO 3 and HClO 4 at a ratio of soil 1:1 (Polish Standard PN-R-04016-21, 1992). In the soil, available K and P were determined by extraction in C 6 H 10 CaO 6, and Ca and Mg were determined by extraction in C 2 H 3 O 2 NH 4 . The contents of K and Ca were measured with atomic emission spectrometry, whereas the Mg content was measured with flame atomic absorption spectroscopy using an iCE 3000 Series. The P content was determined with the Barton method at a wavelength of 470 nm , employing a Marcel s 330 PRO spectrophotometer.

The contents of available micronutrients (Cu, Zn, Fe) and heavy metals (Pb, Cr, Cb, Cd, Ni) were extracted in 1 mol HCl and measured with flame atomic absorption spectroscopy using an iCE 3000 Series with Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry air/acetylene ( Ochmian et al., 2021 ). Assessments of the accuracy and precision of the analytical methods and procedures used were determined using certified reference material: CRM036–050 Loamy Sand 4 (CRM 036–050 produced by Resource Technology Corporation, USA and UK ). The effectiveness of the process was validated with 90–95% efficiency. The results shown are the average of three measurements, working standards made from Merck standards with a concentration of 1000 mg /dm3. The limits of detection were as follows (mg/kg): Ca 0.004; Mg 0.002; K 0.001; Na 0.004; Fe 0.004; Cd 0.003; Co 0.010; Cu 0.005; Ni 0.008; Pb 0.013; Zn 0.003 and Mn 0.002. Tests were performed in three replications.

4.2.3.2. Plants. The contents of elements in plants were determined after mineralization: Mg, P, K and Ca were measured after wet mineralization in H 2 SO 4 and HClO 4 . The contents of Cu, Pb, Cr, Ni, Cb, Cd, Zn and Fe were determined after mineralization in HNO 3 and HClO 4 at a ratio of plants of 3:1 (IUNG, 1990). The K content was measured with atomic emission spectrometry, and the Mg Ca, Cu, Pb, Cr, Ni, Cb, Cd, Zn and Fe contents were measured with flame atomic absorption spectroscopy (iCE 3000 Series). The efficiency of the process was validated with 90–95% success using certified reference materials, namely, tea leaves (INCT-TL-1) and a mixture of Polish herbs (INCT-MPH-2), both produced by the Institute of Nuclear Chemistry and Technology, Warsaw, Poland , which was assessed by the colourimetric method. All tests were performed in three replications.

Extraction of a compound mixture of organs (flowers, stems, fruits, leaves, separately) from the parasite and hosts was performed using 70% ethanol at 20 ◦ C for 60 min with constant stirring. Following centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 10 min, the supernatant was filtered under reduced pressure through a cellulose membrane with a 1.2 μm pore diameter, and the supernatant was concentrated at 40 ◦ C in a vacuum evaporator to remove acetone. Subsequently, the aqueous phase was diluted with water. The plant extract was serially diluted using redistilled water to obtain a gradient of concentrations for use in analytical and biological activity assays ( Ochmian et al., 2019 ).
The flowers and stems from the parasite and flowers, fruits and leaves from the hosts were extracted as described by Lachowicz et al. (2019) . All extractions were performed in triplicate.

2,2 ′ -azo-bis-3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid (ABTS•+) was used to observe the enzyme kinetics of assays Cai et al. (2018) . Additionally, DPPH (1,1-diphenyl-2-picrylhydrazyl) and the ferric reducing antioxidant property (FRAP) were also determined ( Akar et al., 2017 ; Benzie and Devaki, 2018 ). The antioxidant capacity was expressed as umol T/g distilled water. ABTS•+ and FRAP assay measurements were carried out on a UV-2401 PC spectrophotometer. The effect of the activity of the extracts on the enzymes, α- glucosidase lipase and α- amylase, was determined ( Nickavar and Yousefian, 2011 ; Podsedek et al., 2014 ). All samples were assayed in triplicate, and the result was expressed as IC 50 , which is the amount of inhibitor (expressed as mg of fruit per mL of the reaction mixture, under assay conditions) required to inhibit 50% of enzyme activity. The amount of nitrates was measured using a RQflex 10 requantometer (Merck) ( Mijowska et al., 2016 ). All samples were assayed in triplicate.

heading.emphasis: 4.5. Analysis of polyphenolic compounds using the UPLC-PDA-ESI-MS/

subSection.paragraph:
Polyphenolic compounds were analysed using a UPLC-PDA-ESI-MS/ MS Waters ACQUITY system (Waters, Milford, MA, USA ) as method described by Kapusta et al. (2018) for polyphenolic compounds, a lower concentration of formic acid was used (0.1% v/v). The program was set as follows: 0 min 5% B; 0–8 min, linear to 100% B; 8–9.5 min, washing, and back to initial condition. The sample injection volume was 5 μl. The polyphenolic compound detection and identification were based on the specific PDA spectra, mass to charge ratio, and fragment ions obtained following collision-induced dissociation (CID). Additional settings are enlisted in
Table 1
in Appendix. Quantification was achieved by injecting solutions of known concentrations, ranging from 0.05 to 5 mg /mL (R 2 ≤ 0.9998), of phenolic compounds as standards. Waters MassLynx software v.4.1 was used for data acquisition and processing. The sample measurement was done in triplicate, and expressed as mg/ 100 g (DW).

All statistical analyses were performed using Statistica 13.1 (StatSoft Polska , Cracow, Poland ). Statistical significance of the differences between means was determined by testing the homogeneity of variance and normality of distribution, followed by ANOVA with Tukey’ s post hoc test. The significance was set at p < 0.05. The multidimensional analysis was carried out using the analysis of the main components (PCA). The data were scaled during pre-processing automatically.
